fields.Title of Presentation: <span><span style="font-size:11pt;color:#1f1f1f;background-color:transparent;font-weight:bold;">The Wisdom of Embodied Experience in an Age of AI</span></span>
fields.Conference/Meeting Name: Kern Partners for Character and Educational Leadership (KPCEL)
fields.Description/Abstract: <span style="font-weight:400;">Traditionally, the west has understood “humanity” by using nature and animality as a foil—by contrasting it with cultural achievements, language and learning. Recent advances in AI, however, have put anthropological designations like </span><span style="font-weight:400;">homo faber </span><span style="font-weight:400;">or</span><span style="font-weight:400;"> homo linguisticus</span><span style="font-weight:400;"> into question. The result is what Santoro and Monin have dubbed the “AI Effect”, a broad redefining of the human that brings new attributes to the fore. Despite all they can do, AI systems are unable to realize human realities essential to our </span><span style="font-weight:400;">having</span><span style="font-weight:400;"> (having feelings, relationships, perspectives, etc.) and our </span><span style="font-weight:400;">being</span><span style="font-weight:400;"> (our being moral, mortal, physical, etc.). We both </span><span style="font-weight:400;">have</span><span style="font-weight:400;"> and </span><span style="font-weight:400;">are</span><span style="font-weight:400;"> our bodies. Being, having, and embodiment together form the basis on which our values, practical wisdom, and character are realized.</span>
